subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: QS news update
msgSnippet: ... Rhotics who make them the same make them all SQUARE.  Those who make them all different (basically the East Coast and the South, plus the rhotic areas
messageBody:
Paul Tremblay scripsit:

> Or, we can put it this way. What letters do we use for Mary the name;
> Marry, as in marriage; and merry?

Rhotics who make them the same make them all SQUARE. Those who make them
all different (basically the East Coast and the South, plus the rhotic
areas outside North America) have SQUARE in "Mary", TRAP in "marry", and
DRESS in "merry". Some folks have two alike and one different: my wife
(from North Carolina) puts "Mary" and "merry" in SQUARE, "marry" in TRAP.

The one that's in NURSE is "Murray". Some people, notably in
Philadelphia, put both "Murray" and "merry" in NURSE, but "marry" is
still in TRAP and "Mary" in SQUARE, as elsewhere on the East Coast.

As I posted before, non-rhotics use FACE in "Mary".

> I too find those missing Ts a problem. I pronounce
> the T in words like "Saturday" with a T. The dictionary I use drops
> them. I think most people would be more comfortable with these Ts in
> place. Let me know of any other spellings you find strange. It helps me
> out greatly.

CMU makes it S AE T ER D IY, which is See-At-Tea-Utter-Roe-Day-Eat.
(My wife pronounces the days of the week with full Day-Ate, like the
word "day", and claims that I talk like a gangster because I say
Tea-Ooze-Zoo-Day-Eat instead of Tea-Ye-Ooze-Zoo-Day-Ate.)

I note that CMU does not merge D and T between vowels, though practically
everybody in North America does. It's artificial, all right, but for
our purposes that's useful.

--
Income tax, if I may be pardoned for saying so, John Cowan
is a tax on income. --Lord Macnaghten (1901) cowan@...
